cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 255 mi (410 km) S of Kingston, Jamaica
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to turn NW then N-NNW, cross western Cuba Monday night, enter the southeast Gulf, and curve N-NE toward the Florida peninsula before moving inland toward GA/SC late Thu–Fri.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida west coast (likely near the Tampa Bay–Big Bend region)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Tropical Storm Watch for Little Cayman and Cayman Brac
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Florida Keys and peninsula first, then Atlantic coast from NE Florida through Georgia and South Carolina late week
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Possible (guidance suggests 4–6 inches if the core passes inland nearby)
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Possible but uncertain (depends on exact inland track and coastal orientation)
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (39–57 mph) are possible late Thu into Fri with a 15 % cumulative chance; 50-kt winds currently <3 %.
weather_observation.storm_surge: If Ian exits into the western Atlantic near GA/SC, a 2–4 ft surge could occur; confidence still low five days out.
weather_observation.rainfall: Heavy rain bands could bring 4–6 in. with localized higher amounts, producing flash/urban flooding around the port.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Brief tornadoes in outer rain-bands, rough seas and dangerous rip currents likely to disrupt vessel scheduling.
